PDFParser API Reference

PDFParser is a Python library for extracting structured content from PDF documents. It provides a simple, intuitive API for parsing PDFs into machine-readable formats.

Version: 1.0.0
Last Updated: 2025-01-15

Installation

Install via pip:

pip install pdfparser

Or install from source:

git clone https://github.com/example/pdfparser.git
cd pdfparser
pip install -e .

Quick Start

Here's a simple example to get you started:

from pdfparser import PDFParser

# Initialize parser
parser = PDFParser()

# Parse a PDF file
document = parser.parse("document.pdf")

# Access extracted content
print(f"Title: {document.metadata.title}")
print(f"Pages: {document.page_count}")
print(f"Tables: {len(document.tables)}")

API Reference

PDFParser

The main class for PDF parsing.

Constructor

PDFParser(config: Optional[PDFConfig] = None)

Parameters:

  • config (PDFConfig, optional) - Configuration options for parsing

Methods

parse()
parse(
    pdf_path: Union[str, Path],
    category: Optional[DocumentCategory] = None
) -> SimpleDocument

Parse a PDF file and extract structured content.

Parameters:

  • pdf_path (str or Path) - Path to PDF file
  • category (DocumentCategory, optional) - Document category hint

Returns:

  • SimpleDocument - Parsed document with extracted content

Raises:

  • FileNotFoundError - If PDF file doesn't exist
  • PDFParseError - If parsing fails

Example:

from pathlib import Path
from pdfparser import PDFParser, DocumentCategory

parser = PDFParser()
doc = parser.parse(
    Path("paper.pdf"),
    category=DocumentCategory.ACADEMIC_PAPER
)

print(doc.metadata.title)
for table in doc.tables:
    print(table.data)
Note: The category parameter helps optimize extraction for specific document types. If not provided, the parser will attempt to auto-detect.
parse_batch()
parse_batch(
    pdf_paths: List[Path],
    max_workers: int = 4
) -> List[SimpleDocument]

Parse multiple PDF files in parallel.

Parameters:

  • pdf_paths (List[Path]) - List of PDF file paths
  • max_workers (int) - Maximum number of parallel workers

Returns:

  • List[SimpleDocument] - List of parsed documents

SimpleDocument

Represents a parsed document with extracted content.

Attributes

  • id (str) - Unique document identifier
  • format (DocumentFormat) - Source format (PDF, HTML, etc.)
  • metadata (DocumentMetadata) - Title, authors, dates, etc.
  • content (List[ContentElement]) - Main content elements
  • tables (List[TableElement]) - Extracted tables
  • figures (List[FigureElement]) - Extracted figures
  • links (List[LinkElement]) - Extracted links

Examples

Extract Tables

from pdfparser import PDFParser

parser = PDFParser()
doc = parser.parse("report.pdf")

for table in doc.tables:
    print(f"Table {table.id}:")
    print(f"  Caption: {table.caption}")
    print(f"  Rows: {len(table.data)}")
    print(f"  Columns: {len(table.data[0]) if table.data else 0}")

Extract Figures

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from pdfparser import PDFParser

parser = PDFParser()
doc = parser.parse("paper.pdf")

for i, figure in enumerate(doc.figures):
    print(f"Figure {i+1}: {figure.caption}")

    # Save figure image
    if figure.image_data:
        with open(f"figure_{i+1}.png", "wb") as f:
            f.write(figure.image_data)

Custom Configuration

from pdfparser import PDFParser, PDFConfig

config = PDFConfig(
    extract_images=True,
    extract_tables=True,
    dpi=300,
    language="en"
)

parser = PDFParser(config=config)
doc = parser.parse("document.pdf")
Warning: High DPI settings (>300) may significantly increase processing time and memory usage for large documents.
